fields.description:
My instinct when wanting to find something is to hit ⌘-F, but in SourceTree, ⌘-3 is the way this is done.

Perhaps also Find is a drop-in pane like Safari and Xcode do against the currently visible contents instead of it's own view mode?
fields.summary: Search isn't bound to ⌘-F

fields.description: In Tower they have a "Browse" view, which allows you to browse and open files in the project tree in state as it is in any chosen commit, while retaining the existing working tree. This allows to edit files in the working tree while being able to refer to their state in other commits or branches. This is very powerful.
fields.summary: Browse commit inside SourceTree

fields.description: i.e. not the current branch but just a currently selected branch. This is the default behaviour in "Tower" and it's proven to be very useful for quick analysis of histories of other branches
fields.summary: In the log show history of a currently selected branch in the "Branches" list

fields.description: Say, I have a branch with name "structure/main", it appears in the {{Branches}} list on the left as a folder "structure" with "main" inside. When I have some such folders unfolded and I perform a switch between branches, they all fold.
fields.summary: All unfolded branches having name with slashes fold when a branch is changed

fields.description:
If you change the bookmark name when you've already opened the repository, any changes do not get reflected in the window title until you restart SourceTree (even closing and re-opening the window keeps the old title).

The title should update as soon as the bookmark name is changed.
fields.summary: Renaming a bookmark for an already open repo window doesn't propagate to window title until restart

fields.description: Just wondering if you guys have any plans to build a windows or linux version of SourceTree. I have colleagues that can't dev on a mac, and we have not found a single comparable product to SourceTree. It's the best and I wish folks on other platforms could see how great it is too.
fields.summary: SourceTree for other Platforms (Windows/Linux)

fields.description:
On the command line, do:
$ svn co http://svn.exactcode.de/exact-image/trunk/ ExactImage

In SourceTree, click File -> Open... and navigate to the ExactImage directory. SourceTree then tells you that "ExactImage does not refer to a working copy for Mercurial, Git or Subversion" (and that sentence is missing a period at the end ;-) ).
fields.summary: (Partial) SVN working tree not recognized

fields.description: The bisect feature of Git and Mercurial are extremely useful in finding when a bug was introduced.  It would be great if SourceTree provided a nice UI (like Git-flow) to select the good and bad change-sets, then iterate through the bisect process.
fields.summary: Support for bisect

fields.description:
I have two git repositories with a slightly different layout (both websites, one with a public_html directory, the other with a httpdocs directory).

When trying to move some changes from one to the other using a Patch file I need  to stripe 2 pieces of the path and set a new Base Path.

The latter (the Base Path) is not processed in the Git command.

The full command by STREE with no trace of my Base Path is:
{{git -c diff.mnemonicprefix=false -c core.quotepath=false apply -v --reject -p 2 /path/to/patch.diff}}

Adding the --directory parameter makes this command work:

{{git -c diff.mnemonicprefix=false -c core.quotepath=false apply -v --reject -p 2 /path/to/patch.diff --directory httpdocs/}}
fields.summary: Git "Apply Patch" functionality does not seem to honor "Base Path" input

fields.description:
SourceTree disables user extensions by default to provide a predictable experience with Mercurial. It does this by scanning the user's ~/.hgrc and generating lines in ST's internal hgrc stack to disable the extensions unless the user specifically re-enables them in Preferences.

However, if the ~/.hgrc uses the %include directive to bring in another configuration file, SourceTree doesn't scan that and so unsupported extensions can leak through to SourceTree, and don't appear in the Preferences.

SourceTree should scan included files too when looking for extensions.
fields.summary: If hg extensions are loaded via %include, ST doesn't detect them

fields.description: It would be great if there was an ability to choose the terminal that gets opened rather than having to only open "terminal" in OSX. I personally use (and I'm sure the guys at Pivotal Labs think so also) use iTerm.
fields.summary: Preference for terminal

fields.description:
Resolve Using Mine" and "Resolve Using Theirs" does not work as expected.

When performing a rebase on a Git Repository, a conflict is identified. The user can use the "Resolve Using Mine" or "Resolve Using Theirs" to quickly resolve the conflict. However, using either of these functions will remove all changes.

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create a new Git Repository
2. Add and commit a new file TEMP.TXT with the text "Hello World"
3. Create a new branch called BranchGoodbye
3a. On BranchGoodbye, edit TEMP.TXT to be "Goodbye World"
4. Checkout master, and create a new branch called BranchAdam
4a. On BranchAdam, edit TEMP.TXT to be "Hello Adam"
5. On BranchAdam, rebase with BranchGoodbye

At Step 5, there will now be a conflict on TEMP.TXT

Notice that using "Resolve Using Mine" and "Resolve Using Theirs" will not work as expected.
fields.summary: Resolving Conflicts using Mine/Theirs during rebase

fields.description:
In Github, when a user adds you to their private repo, that repo is visible on the sourcetree hosted repo list (so i can immediately pull the source). Doing the same/similar action in bitbucket does not show the repo in the sourcetree repo list.

The repo does show under my bitbucket account repository list online, so I would fully expect the repo to be visible in sourcetree.
fields.summary: shared private bitbucket repos not showing in 'hosted repositories' list

fields.description: Currently, blaming a selected file opens up a window showing which lines have been modified in which revision, based on the currently selected revision / revision of your working tree. However, often when blaming a line of code you realize that there was no "real" change / not the change you're interested in in the revision printed next to the line, so you actually would like to do another blame based on the revision from that line. You basically want to jump backwards in history by incrementally blaming a file to find a particular revision which introduces the change of interest in the line of code you're interested in. "git gui blame" implements this feature by clicking on the SHA1 in the gutter. It would be nice to have this feature in SourceTree / for Mercurial, too.
fields.summary: Incrementally blame a file

fields.description:
I observed a weird problem today which might explain some of the transient login prompt issues some people have reported which are not easily reproducible. 

It appears that in some cases, the keychain lookup will fail incorrectly for a single account which has had its details changed, until SourceTree is restarted. The query details do not appear to change and the information is in the keychain correctly, and yet on restart of SourceTree the same keychain lookup starts working. 

The error from the keychain lookup is unfortunately not illustrative:

{noformat}
17/07/2012 10:29:25.524 SourceTree: Error (internetKeychainItemForServer:withUsername:path:port:protocol:) - 
{noformat}

It appears you can provoke this behaviour by using the "Set Password" option in the hosted projects on an account which has an incorrect password. You'll get prompted 3 times for the password (and the API call won't work), but after restarting SourceTree everything is fine again, with no change to any underlying data.
fields.summary: Keychain lookup failing until restart after setting password in hosted projects

fields.description: When a file deletion action is dragged from "Files staged in the index" view to "Files in the working tree" the action disappears and the file gets restored
fields.summary: Deleted file dragging issue

fields.description:
Steps
=====

1. Init git repo and commit first one (Terminal.app)
$ git init test
$ cd test
$ touch hello
$ git add .
$ git commit -m "がぎぐげご"

2. Make some changes
$ touch hello2
$ git add .

3. Open test repo with SourceTree
4. Commit changes (step2) with comment "がぎぐげご"

Probrem
=======

Commit message is same but different encoding

Step1: がぎぐげご (UTF8)
Step4: がぎぐげご (UTF8-MAC)

Expect
======

Step1: がぎぐげご (UTF8)
Step2: がぎぐげご (UTF8)

Info
====
First letter: が
NFC: U+304C (HIRAGANA LETTER GA)
NFD: U+304B U+3099 (HIRAGANA LETTER KA + COMBINING KATAKANA-HIRAGANA VOICED SOUND)


Attached:
- Test repo
- Windows cmd.exe


Please support convert UTF8-MAC (NFD) to UTF8 (NFC)

or

Don't change commit message encoding.
fields.summary: Please support convert UTF8-MAC (NFD) to UTF8 (NFC) in commit message

fields.description:
When using [Quicksilver|http://qsapp.com/], the SourceTree icon displayed is way too low resolution, resulting in a highly pixelated image. See attached image.
The icon in the dock looks fine, the problem is only when using Quicksilver.
fields.summary: Low resolution icon in Quicksilver

fields.description:
At the moment if someone else deletes a remote branch, it won't disappear from your repo unless you use the toolbar Fetch button and check the 'Prune' option. If you fetch from the sidebar, or let the scheduled fetch do that for you, then the remote branch will never disappear.

It would be useful to offer a Preferences option to always prune when fetching so that this happens more predictably.
fields.summary: Add 'Prune when fetching' Preferences option

fields.description:
Hi,
I have to deal with git and SVN repositories.
And I'd love being able to use sourceTree for both especially since I haven't found any good SVN client on MacOSX yet.
Regards,

Rémy
fields.summary: SVN Support

fields.description: In File Status View, add a status icon to folders, not just to files, when the contents of the folder has some changes, in order to be able to see where changes exist also when "Showing all", not only when "Showing pending", just like SVN client Cornerstone.
fields.summary: Add status icon to folders with changes

fields.description:
The dialog which pops up when unshelving has an option which says, in French "Effacer avant d'appliquer". The problem is, "avant" means "before", which is incorrect. The shelve is removed after having been applied. The English text for the same dialog is correct, though.

Suggestion: In french it should say: "Supprimer apres avoir appliquer"
fields.summary: The French localization for the unshelve dialog is wrong

fields.description:
My project has more than one group of people working on it at once, some people are members of more than one group and I would find it useful to be able to search for all their commits in one go rather than having to do one search per person from the search screen.

Can you provide a "more advanced" search feature that allows for more than one search criteria.
fields.summary: Search View - Mutil-faceted search support

fields.description:
I've set up a Git repo with 4 Git remotes and 1 SVN remote. I'm able to fetch, push, merge, commit, etc. But when I click Pull in SourceTree nothing happens. No dialog comes up at all. Same thing if I choose Repository > Pull from the menu. I am able to do a command-line "git pull" or use Tower to connect to that repo and do a pull.

This is happening because the git-svn is broken on that repo

Removing the svn-remote section from the config (.git/config) and deleting the .git/svn folder did the trick. 

However it would be nice if SourceTree gave an error message of some sort rather than just not allowing to pull. Also, since Tower still allowed it, it would be nice if SourceTree didn't break when clicking Pull, but rather if I actually selected the SVN and tried to pull from it (i.e. one step further down the line).
fields.summary: stop ST failing when the svn config is broken

fields.description:
The reddish git logo in the Bookmarks view keeps calling my attention as if there's something I need to pay attention to.

The type of repo isn't really all that important, so I'd think it would be better if it were recast in grayscale.

(Sorry for the bikeshed.)
fields.summary: new reddish git icon in the bookmarks window is distracting

fields.description:
The colours in the git output window (e.g. when doing a 'git pull') could be improved. Every single time I see some red scrolling by, I assume there's been an error, when in fact the command has completed successfully.

Assuming you're not actually parsing the output to decide what's an error and what's not, I'd suggest avoiding red altogether, and sticking to neutral black, greys and blues -- probably best to avoid green too, which also has strong (and potentially misleading) connotations.
fields.summary: git output colours could be improved

fields.description:
When stashing changes, a new Stash Entry is created under the "Stash" category. Clicking on this Stash Entry will display the changes in that stash.

When stashing a large number of changes (33 modified files, 8 new files), not all the files/changes appear when viewing the Stash Entry. This leads the user to perceive that their data/changes have been lost. However, when re-applying the Stash Entry, are changes are applied as expected - this appears to be a display only problem introduced by https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/SRCTREE-783 

Suggestion: Display that there are more changes that have been suppressed
fields.summary: Viewing stash with large number of changes does not display all changes

fields.description: On Mac, I'd expect the tree node to expand when double clicking it. Instead, the selected folder opens in the Finder.
fields.summary: Double-click on a folder in tree view opens folder in Finder

fields.description:
When you click the Settings button in the toolbar, then "Add" button, then "Hosted projects" button, then "Create New Repository" button, after the new repo has been created it is not selected by default in the hosted project list.
When the new hosted repo has been
created, would the user not expect that the new repo was now automatically
selected in the hosted repo list underneath? Else why would they go and
create a new hosted repo at this stage?
fields.summary: Create new repo inside the Settings > Remotes > Add dialog does not select new repo by default

fields.description:
when I go to remove a tag from a commit, it gives me a select dropdown with ALL possible tags in that project. This is super-unfriendly to first find the tags that are applicable for just this commit and then remove them. 
As you can see from the attached screenshot, in the Log view, right click on a commit and click on "Tag..." and then click on Remove Tag. It shows the list of all tags in the repository as opposed to just the tags on the commit that I clicked on.
Can you please filter it down to just the tags applicable for that commit? Thanks.
fields.summary: Remove tag dialog only showing for that commit

fields.description:
There are some warning suppression options which appear on message boxes but which cannot be turned off once enabled without using a 'defaults write' command.

They should actually be displayed in the preferences somewhere, perhaps in another tab if things are getting cramped in the general tab.
fields.summary: Add missing 'suppress' options to preferences

fields.description:
I branched off someone else's branch and the graph doesn't seem to be able to cope with it. `hg serve` shows the correct graph.

I would think this is a fairly common usecase? (feature branch with one or more people creating their own branches off the feature branch to work on particular aspects of that feature)

Compare SourceTree:

!https://jira.atlassian.com/secure/attachment/67370/sourcetree.png!

With `hg serve`:

!https://jira.atlassian.com/secure/attachment/67371/hg%20serve.png!
fields.summary: HG graph does not display correctly when branch parent is another branch

fields.description:
(While there is certainly some PEBKAC in this, there are some workflow issues to notice.)

I'm working with a private branch of a fast-moving open source project (LLVM). I regularly merge my local feature branch with the remote while I work on it to keep my changes current. (See screenshot 1).

I have my feature ready, so now I want to prepare a patch to propose to the community via email.

1. Click Create Patch. (Screenshot 2)
2. I can't easily isolate my changes vs the ones I simply merged in.
2a. I tried clicking the Graph column header to perhaps sort that way. It does nothing.
2b. I finally switch to Ancestor Order and All Branches.
2c. Now I'm able to manually find the changes I locally made since they're mostly clustered at the top. (Screenshot 3)
3. Once I have a set of changes selected, the changes shown cover lots of files that were not actually touched in the selected changes. (Screenshot 3)
4. If I actually create the patch, it does contain only the selected changes. I have to review it as a text file to check it instead of relying on the UI in step 3.
5. I realize now that this patch shows interim changes and I'd really rather provide a collapsed patch with all of my changes instead.
6. Try to figure out how to diff two branches (feature branch (metrenamer) vs master (opensource)). Stumble around and find no way to do this.
7. Realize that with one branch current, I can right-click another branch and Diff against Current. It spins for minutes. It stops spinning. No idea where the diff ended up, if it got saved anywhere.
8. Wonder how I should prep the patch I want now and write up a Jira ticket.
fields.summary: Having trouble prepping a patch

fields.description:
When creating a new tag it would be helpful if the radio button for "Specified Commit" was automatically selected if text is entered into the Commit ID field.

Quickly tabbing into this field and pasting a commit ID then hitting return can lead to a new tag at the current HEAD rather than the expected commit ID that was just entered.
fields.summary: Automatically select "Specified Commit" when entering text into field for new tag

fields.description:
When checking out a remote branch into a new local branch, SourceTree does not run submodule update.  It does however run submodule update when checking out an existing local branch.

Here is the output of checking out a remote branch:
git -c diff.mnemonicprefix=false -c core.quotepath=false checkout -b GoldenThread --track origin/GoldenThread 
Switched to a new branch 'GoldenThread'
M	SiREAL_SDK/ARToolKit
Branch GoldenThread set up to track remote branch GoldenThread from origin.
Completed successfully

Now if I checkout master then re-checkout my local branch then I get:
git -c diff.mnemonicprefix=false -c core.quotepath=false checkout GoldenThread 
Switched to branch 'GoldenThread'
M	SiREAL_SDK/ARToolKit


git -c diff.mnemonicprefix=false -c core.quotepath=false submodule update --init --recursive 
Submodule path 'SiREAL_SDK/ARToolKit': checked out '39dca40097b0ad6c70fcc588f5f41b8d07b310b4'
Completed successfully

This requires me to manually run submodule update when I first checkout a branch.
fields.summary: Checkout new branch does not perform submodule update

fields.description: If I un-check "Commit merge immediately", I would expect merge result left in working copy without commit. However commit is performed always. It looks like this check box is simply ignored
fields.summary: Unable to skip commit on merge

fields.description:
I have multiple remotes in my GIT repo...often some of them are offline but it seems that if that's the case, ORIGIN (the only remote I actually care to get auto-updates from) never gets auto-checked.

Ideally, it'd be nice for users to be able to select which remotes they want to auto-update from but a simpler solution would be to just not early-exit when encountering a remote that's offline...continue checking the others for updates.
fields.summary: Offline Remotes Prevent Auto-Remote Updates

fields.description:
The other day I was having trouble finding a commit from the Search View. I knew the keywords matched as I could find it manually in the Log View.

Finally figured out that the upper bound of the date filter was a couple days prior instead of being current. I had SourceTree running for a couple days and it didn't roll over when the system clock did. The computer is typically in sleep mode at night.

Maybe there should be a way to indicate always to use 'today' as the upper bound for this filter?
fields.summary: Upper bound date in log search can get left behind the times

fields.description:
The Description detail pane doesn't handle right-click with the usual context menu.

1. Select a change that has a URL in the description text.
2. Note that the URL isn't underlined.
3. Drag-select the URL.
4. Right click the selection.
5. Note that the usual context menu (with the Open URL Service) doesn't appear.

In my case, there was a URL for a GitHub issue discussed in the description.
fields.summary: Description pane text doesn't handle inline URLs

fields.description:
On lower-end machines it's possible to overload the machine with calls to hg/git because of the way GCD interprets calls which it considers to be blocked on I/O.

SourceTree schedules all of its work through Grand Central Dispatch, which deals with thread pools based on the number of CPU cores available. This should mean that things are scaled appropriately based on the machine, however it was revealed to me in a lab session that GCD is a bit smarter than that - it detects if any of those threads is currently waiting for file I/O or similar, and if so fires up another thread to deal with the next request in the mean time. Unfortunately, calls to Mercurial are seen like this, so GCD goes beyond the 2-4 threads and starts firing up new ones to service more Python calls. On a low-end machine the hg calls probably don't clear quick enough, and this becomes a snowball effect (the 2GB starts to run out, making each hg call slower, which means GCD thinks they're blocked on I/O more so launches more threads etc etc). You just don't see this on other machines (and I test on my wife's 5-year old Core Duo MBP, but it has 4GB and the hg calls seem to clear quick enough for the pile-up not to happen).

The main culprit here is likely to be the bookmarks window, although in theory any view could trigger it with enough queued work.

Unfortunately to maintain 10.6 compatibility we can't just use a custom dispatch queue set to concurrent (only serial custom queues are supported in 10.6, and those serialise things too much - on testing this the bookmarks window feels interminably slow). The better option might be to monitor the number of outstanding calls in the bookmarks window much like the Hosted Projects window and limit it to queueing a max of (say) 3-4 to GCD at any one time.
fields.summary: Manually throttle Bookmarks workload more closely

fields.description:
In the drop down box for filtering the view by file status ("Show Pending", "Show Conflicts" etc.), please add a filter named "Show Changed" which shows tracked files only which have changed (were modified, added, removed, etc.). So this is basically as "Show Pending" but with untracked files removed from the view, just like the output of "hg status -q".

I was thinking to suggest the name "Show Modified" at first, but that seems to be misleading as one might think it refers to modified and not added / removed files only, so I think "Show Changed" is the better name.
fields.summary: Add a "Show Changed" filter

fields.description: Working on Drupal issues, people upload patches to review (for example http://drupal.org/files/upload_form_bugs.patch), those have full URLs, it would be nice if we could paste these URLs into SourceTree.
fields.summary: Apply patch from URL

fields.description: If you have '-' character in the beginning of a folder - you can't add files to GIT/HG repos and the diff operation fail as well.
fields.summary: Handle minuses in folder names

fields.description: I like to review my diffs before staging them, and SourceTree helps by showing me the diffs for all selected files on the right side. It would be nice, however, if the diff actions (Stage File, Unstage File, Discard Changes) could be kept visible even when I scroll down.
fields.summary: Keep the diff actions (stage, unstage, discard) always visible

fields.description:
The internal diff shows red and green lines for the changes, but not what changed inside the line.  So for a long line with a tiny change, you go hunting.  Let the computer do the hunting.

(Also, it would be nice to be able to enable wrapping of the diffs.)
fields.summary: Internal diff needs to show what has changed in a line

fields.description:
See Screencast:
http://screencast.com/t/ZfB968Ge6l
fields.summary: Setting a username in the project config adds a space character

fields.description: For master/slaves repo structures (you pull from the salves, you push to the master) should be nice to define a default repo for each case. If not (and no standard default repo is defined), the red bubbles in the pull and push green arrows were not updated with the incoming and outcoming changes
fields.summary: Separated default pull and default push repos

fields.description: When pulling from the repo, if you use the progress extension in the CLI, you can see the remaining time and status of the current task. Should be nice to have this reflected in the SourceTree progress bar that only have a "undefined" state.
fields.summary: Progress bar to work actually
New Japanese mistranslations

fields.description: When in the Bookmarks view it would be great if it were possible to perform a pull / push for a repository right there in the bookmarks window without having to first open each repository that needs action.
fields.summary: Add support for Pull/Push from bookmarks view.

fields.description:
It would be great if it were possible to add/import an entire folder of repositories into bookmarks in a single step. Or part thereof if some of the repositories have already been imported.

Bonus points if SourceTree were able to continue to monitor folders for new projects and prompt you if you would like to import them when it detects a previously unseen project has been added to said folder.
fields.summary: Add/Import a folder of projects to bookmarks

fields.description:
A pretty typical corporate workflow for an open source project:

1. A git remote for the project. (llvm.org in my case).
2. A desktop at the office.
3. A laptop.

On the laptop, I have the desktop set as a remote with a path that requires VPN to work remotely (a 10.x.x.x address over Juniper's VPN client or a direct LAN connection in the office).

Fetches from the laptop could be aware of the accessibility of the desktop paths and improve behavior when the VPN is down. As is, I have to right-click the open source remote and fetch from that explicitly instead of clicking the big Fetch button or relying on the background fetches.

I could see this as requiring a special path construction or a config flag for the remote that ties it to an interface or some other way to identify the VPN.
fields.summary: working with remotes that are on VPNs

fields.description: Although most commands don't work with folders, both git and hg allow you to specify a folder parameter to the log command. When using tree or column view this should be available on the folders too.
fields.summary: Log selected on folders

fields.description:
Auto-upgrading from 1.4.3.1 to the 1.4.4 or 1.4.4.1/2 versions did not work for me. Sparkle's error handling was unhelpful and just backed out of the process. I eventually installed a fresh 1.4.4.2 to work around this.

The console output was similarly unhelpful in identifying the root cause:
6/14/12 1:04:00 PM	[0x0-0x1c61c6].com.torusknot.SourceTreeNotMAS[8457]	"disk5" unmounted.
6/14/12 1:04:00 PM	[0x0-0x1c61c6].com.torusknot.SourceTreeNotMAS[8457]	"disk5" ejected.
6/14/12 1:04:01 PM	SourceTree[8457]	Sparkle Error: An error occurred while extracting the archive. Please try again later.

Earlier Sparkle upgrades had worked smoothly.
fields.summary: Sparkle failure

fields.description:
It'd be great if one could not only see in the Bookmarks window that there are non-pushed changesets. 

Adding push functionality to Bookmarks would make users wait less when only pushes need to be done. Opening the repository window often takes a few seconds: frustrating when I don't have to commit anything and when I don't have to see the history; when I instead only want to push things into the default/origin repositories of those four repos I forgot to push after committing.
fields.summary: Push from Bookmarks dialog

fields.description: It would be great to have the possibility to assign custom colors to branches so that, switching between them, they keep consistent. You could just add a squared selector to the right of the branch in the sidebar.
fields.summary: Custom colors for branches

fields.description: It would be great to be able to browse, while creating a new repo from a working copy, bundles packages. E.g. Rapidweaver themes are bundles, and I have to drad and drop its packages content in the browse window and, once selected, delete the final path to make SourceTree see is as a folder… :)
fields.summary: Browsing Mac OS X packages

fields.description:
WWDC 2012 saw the release of the new MacBook with retina display, which doubles the resolution of the screen. The following issues need to be addressed to support this fully:

# Retina-quality application icon (Joel is already on this)
# Double-resolution icons (named foo@2x.png etc)
# Possibly switch to using [NSView centerScanRect] instead of adding 0.5 manually to coordinates to place lines / boxes on precise pixels for sharp rendering
# Possibly alter the way that the 'badges' for pull / push toolbar icons are rendered, to handle windows changing screens with different pixel multipliers

Many of the 16x16 icons already have 32x32 equivalents available from their original icon libraries, although many of these have been altered to compose imagery, add/remove shadows or change the colour balance so there is still some work required. The toolbar icons however do not have any high resolution options already available and will need to be drawn again.
fields.summary: MacBook with retina display refinements

fields.description:
I'm not sure how useful this would be in practice, just a random idea.

Drag and drop between repos. For example: Bookmarks, shelved items. Maybe dragging a file with changes onto another working copy and auto apply the changes from the dragged files.
fields.summary: Drag and Drop Support

fields.description:
I like beautiful commit messages. Most people using git like it too, and what consists a beautiful message has been nicely summarized by Tim Pope here:

http://tbaggery.com/2008/04/19/a-note-about-git-commit-messages.html

And while this is about git, mercurial repositories would probably benefit from the same conventions.

So, I'd love if SourceTree could help me writing those messages. For example, it could render the first line of the message in *bold*, and somehow signal if I go over 50 characters for that line. For the rest of the commit message, it should automatically insert line breaks at 72 characters, inserting spaces for indentations when it looks like I'm typing a bullet list.

Another option would be embedding Emacs as the commit message editor (I'm half joking about this).
fields.summary: Better formatting for commit messages

fields.description:
I like, no NEED, word-based diff to make my life bearable. Apple's FileMerge and Xcode internal diff tool get this very, very right. Unfortunately, SourceTree is a much better VCS client application, particularly when using the internal diff view, so it appears that my life will never be complete.

Thanks!
fields.summary: Word-based diff option in internal diff viewer

fields.description:
When I use the Check for Updates function, version 1.4.4 is found. The package downloads fine but fails every time the .dmg file is extracted and is being moved into Applications. This error has happened consistently today on different machines running OSX 10.6.8

Error: Update Error! "An error occurred while extracting the archive. Please try again later."
fields.summary: Automatic update to version 1.4.4 wont work on OSX 10.6.8

fields.description:
SourceTree is very CPU intense (see Screenshot)
(and the cpu fan gets quite annoying)

force quit produced the attached crash report
fields.summary: CPU Usage of over 500%

fields.description:
Hi i'm fresh here.

I love using CLI tools(w/ App store version) it helps me a lot. By the way it is lazy to open help file, search and hit `command line tools`, download it then install pkg.

Please ask me the prompt when Setup wizard like GitHub.app ...
fields.summary: CLI tools

fields.description:
With the probable release of Retina displays for Mac in the fairly near future (perhaps even at WWDC 2012 although I'm not sure the tech is ready for the right price yet), suddenly all the bitmaps in SourceTree will start to look pixellated compared to the text / vector drawing. The only way to resolve this will be to re-draw all the icons at double the resolution - in practice in fact we'll need the icons to be drawn explicitly at both resolution types in order to be sharp on all configurations.

So, we'll probably need to get a designer working in Illustrator or similar to make this happen. There are quite a lot of icons so this isn't a small job, but it would probably be good to get some professional work on the functional icons too anyway (as opposed to the app icon which has already been done).

You can see how this looks by doing the following even on a non-Retina Mac:

# Install the XCode tools
# Launch Quartz Debug from /Developer/Applications/Graphics Tools
# Click the Window Menu, then UI Resolution
# Check the 'Enable HiDPI display modes' option
# Log out and log back in
# Open System Preferences > Displays
# Select a resolution that ends in "(HiDPI)"

Everything will be double the usual size since the hardware can't actually display the resolution otherwise, but you can see the effect.
fields.summary: HiDPI compatible icons

fields.description:
In the other Git GUIs that I'm familiar with, such as GitX and GitExtensions, double-clicking a file in the working tree pane moves it to the index pane. (And double-clicking a file in the index pane moves it back to the working tree pane.)

In SourceTree, I keep inadvertently opening XCode because my muscle memory tells me to double-click a filename. I don't want to open XCode. I don't use it and it's slow to start up.

Please consider changing the behavior of double-clicking a filename, or at least making it configurable.
fields.summary: Double-Clicking in Working Tree Pane should Stage files

fields.description:
When you merge or rebase explicitly, errors are accepted & post-processed in order to give the friendly merge notification and to close the window anyway.

However when there's a conflict during the pull process in git (including if you use the rebase option), you get the error in the task window, and then have to Cancel the underlying dialog afterwards in order to proceed to resolving the conflicts. This is confusing and should operate the same way as the explicit merge process.

This may also be the case for the Mercurial pull process if the merge post-process operation is used.
fields.summary: Merge conflicts during git pull cause pull window not to close

fields.description:
If you have a commit selected in the log view which you subsequently rebase, the SHA gets altered. If after the rebase the log view tries to re-select the SHA, it will never find it, and in fact it will end up loading the log forever back to the very first commit looking for it. This is very inefficient and on large repositories it can seem to the user that the spinner will never finish.

In order to head that problem off, we should check the existence of a SHA before embarking on the search for it in the log.

Implementation: 

hg id -r SHA
git show -s --oneline SHA

Return code on both is 0 only if the SHA exists.
fields.summary: On rebase, re-selection of commit can end up spinning forever

fields.description: If you change a commit mode from "staged changes" to "selected files" next time this dialog box will be opened the setting is reverted back to "staged changes".
fields.summary: Commit Dialog Box does not remember "Commit Mode"

fields.description:
Right now the size of each tab is derived solely from the base size contained in the XIB on loading. This means if the view is resizable, on opening the sheet for a second time, the last used size is not remembered. Switching tabs while the sheet is open does remember the size.

Perhaps we could detect if the parent window has an autosave name, and if so derive a prefs setting name for each tab (if the window is resizable) which is then used to derive the window size on opening instead of the default size. This would then have to be manually saved when the window is closed.

Will definitely be a change to SSSelectableToolbar, but the sheets affected are:

* Settings sheet
* Create Patch sheet
* Apply Patch sheet
fields.summary: Allow sheets which use SSSelectableToolbar to remember their size per tab

fields.description:
The pull count as displayed e.g. as an overlay to the "Pull" toolbar icon should (optionally) refer to the current branch only, because that's what you're mostly interested in: Whether there are new commits on your branch. Moreover, it helps to vastly shorten the time required to get the incoming changes for large repositories.

The GUI for this basically is already there: One would just have to make any changes to the "Branch" field in the "Advanced" section of the "Pull" dialog sticky, and adjust the pull count according to the selected branch.

On a related note, it is confusing that "Incoming changes" do not change when selecting a branch.

The related Atlassian Answers entry is at:
https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/58894/how-to-limit-pull-count-to-current-branch
fields.summary: Mercurial pull count should refer to current branch only

fields.description: "Settings" popup window do not remember it's state (window size, etc).
fields.summary: "Settings" popup window do not remember it's state (window size, etc).

fields.description: "Create Patch" popup window do not remember it's state (window size, etc).
fields.summary: "Create Patch" popup window do not remember it's state (window size, etc)

fields.description:
If SourceTree is not running, and the last time it was shut down the bookmarks window was closed, when launching SourceTree for a repo from the command line using 'stree', the Bookmarks window should not open again. Currently, it does just before the repo is opened.

The reason for this is likely to be init timing. The bookmarks view is opened because there are no other windows at the time, but actually there's a window pending being opened from the command line. So in fact, there is no reason to open the bookmarks view. It is still valid to open the bookmarks window if there are no open windows, but only if there isn't one pending.
fields.summary: Bookmarks window shouldn't always open if ST is launched from 'stree'

fields.description:
1. Right-click a branch name and select "Rename..."
2. A rename dialog appears, but the focus isn't in the text entry field.
3. It's necessary to click to be able to type the new name. Hitting TAB doesn't move the focus to the text entry field either.
fields.summary: Branch rename dialog doesn't come up with focus

fields.description: It is very useful feature, but currently lack of
fields.summary: To add squash commit functionality

fields.description:
When I want to push my changes automatically all the local branches are checked for pushing.

Problem:
Most of the time colleagues are working on the other branches or changes happen to the master. I get an error I can't push before I pull those other branches disrupting my workflow. 
My current workflow is to twice use the select all checkbox to deselect all branches (Can have a dozen) and select only the branch to push. This is very cumbersome to always have to do those actions.

Solution:

Remember the last selected push branches while you remain on the same branch
Autoselect only current branch after switching.
Make auto select all an option.
fields.summary: Only check the current branch when pushing

fields.description: Raised by @marcransome: "I often lose my place in the log table when reviewing old code. How about a shortcut that scrolls to the selected commit?"
fields.summary: Scroll to existing selection in log view with shortcut / menu item

fields.description: Will the GIT logo that is currently in ST be updated with the new official GIT logo ?
fields.summary: Update GIT logo

fields.description:
Unable to remove tag. Click "Tag" icon on toolbar. Select "Remove Tag" tab. Choose a tag. Click "Delete". Tag is not deleted.
See attached screencast for illustration
fields.summary: Unable to remove tag if using the toolbar icons

fields.description:
SRCTREE-756 added recursive updating of submodules, which is good, but occasionally, I need to clone a repository non-recursively.

Forcing recursive cloning means that what would habe been a task of a few minutes becomes a very time consuming fetch of a load of submodules that I didn't need.

Having recursive as the default option sounds like the right thing, but having an advanced option to turn it off would be useful too.
fields.summary: Have switching off recursive cloning as an advanced option

fields.description: It would be great I we could pull from or push to a cluster of repositories with a single action, since we use small but many repositories. It would be ok if this is applicable only to a selected group of bookmarks instead of an arbitrary selection of repositories.
fields.summary: Push/pull multiple repositories in one go

fields.description:
- the 'check default remotes for updates' general option is enabled (every 10 minutes)
- 'automatically refresh' and 'refresh ... in background' options in advanced repository settings are enabled for all repositories
- remote commits are not refreshed/updated in the bookmark list, even when waiting for hours
- manual refresh (Cmd-R) or application restart properly refreshes by force
- in the bookmark list, there are ~30 small Git repositories (260 MB, none > 1000 commits; very few branches, most repositories without) hosted on private remote servers and accessed via https using non-/self-signed certificates ([http] sslverify=false)
- there is *one* origin path given for every repository
- I can occasionally see progress indicators on bookmark list entries but remote commits are not displayed, even when the are already there
- when opening a repository, the pull count (outdated in bookmark view) is properly shown within 1-2 seconds 
- this *worked* in an older version of SourceTree (possibly 1.2.4.1, not sure) on OSX 10.6; SourceTree and system were both in place updated since then
fields.summary: no automatic/background refresh of the remote Git commit count in bookmark view

fields.description: Please see attached picture. Why do you display a file name inside a diff window (outlined in red). It takes precious vertical space (less code is displayed) and besides, this name is already selected and visible to user in filelist window (outlined in green) ? Maybe it will be a good idea to remove it from diff window ? Also the icon and text "Modified file" are not necessary as icon is already displayed in filelist window and by itself represents that the file was modified. If you remove it it will make the diff window very clean and easy for eyes.
fields.summary: Diff Window UI Changes

fields.description:
"Pull" dialog box does not remember it's settings. 
I selected "Include messages from commits being merged in merge commit" option, but the next time I clicked "Pull" icon this option was unchecked.
fields.summary: "Pull" dialog box does not remember it's settings.

fields.description:
The selected commit is lost when the dialog box opens up and if you've got tons of commits then you need to scroll down and find the correct one:
http://screencast.com/t/XFIMbyyfR
fields.summary: Checkout dialog box doesn't automatically select the highlighted changeset

fields.description:
If a submodule is added to a branch (the master branch for instance, see "master" attachement) and then all changes are committed there. Then a second branch is checked out (see "Branch" attachment"; then this second branch seems to have "uncomitted changes" associated to it. 

However, when switching to File Status View, the list is empty. Furthermore, Reset is disabled.

I would have expected either:
1. The files in the submodules are listed in the File Status View
2. The submodules are not listed as Uncommited Changes
fields.summary: Switching branches when using Submodules displays "uncommited changes"

fields.description: "Log Selected" & "Blame Selected" popup windows do not remember it's state (window size, etc) & settings (like: "follow renamed files" checked) after closing.
fields.summary: "Log Selected" & "Blame Selected" popup windows do not remember it's state

fields.description:
When you go to delete a GIT tag the confirm dialog box shows up with an checkbox which doesn't have any affect:
http://screencast.com/t/FyW5Q8Xeao9H
fields.summary: Strange delete tag dialog box

fields.description:
Can you please add GitLabHG https://github.com/gitlabhq/gitlabhq as an hosted repository service?
This would be awesome!
fields.summary: Add GitlabHG as Hosted Repository Service

fields.description:
when looking at the folder list in Sourcetree, even with 'Show All' selected, empty folders are not visible.

Apart from anything else, this prevents the user from ignoring folder contents (eg cache/log folders, which would be empty to start).

Current workaround is to add a file (even if any empty file) to the directory, which will then force it to show. However this is highly inconvient and inefficient.
fields.summary: Empty folders not showing in Sourcetree

fields.description:
Our workflow involves always putting a change request id in the commit message. If we want to cherry-pick a change request which involved multiple commits, I go to the search view in SourceTree, search for the commits, copy the SHA-1 code, go to the log view, jump to the SHA-1, then cherry pick.

It would be a lot nicer if I could search for the change request in the search view, then mulit-select the matching commits and cherry-pick.
fields.summary: Ability to cherry-pick from the search view

fields.description: It could be great if we were able to do a search on any commits by a small group of users. E.g. search by the regular expression (Stephen|Monica|Chris).
fields.summary: Support regular expressions in the search view

fields.description:
Git has a commit message convention that comment message lines should be manually wrapped to e.g. 72 characters. The SourceTree comment message box has no information about the line length to assist in doing manual wrapping. E.g. GitX has a vertical guide in the edit dialog to show the preferred wrapping column, with a preference setting to hiding the guide and defining the guide column placement. SourceTree should have a similar guide to help in manual line wrapping.

References to line wrapping convention:

[http://tbaggery.com/2008/04/19/a-note-about-git-commit-messages.html]
[https://github.com/torvalds/subsurface/blob/master/README#L161]
fields.summary: Show column guide in commit message edit dialog

fields.description:
Seems like something useful and/or pretty could be done with the git-svn-id log lines. They always distract me into reading them because of their placement at the end of the log message but they're really metadata.

My first instinct is to not display them directly, but have some other way to see the associated svn revision number.
fields.summary: do something useful/pretty with git-svn-id log lines

fields.description:
I always run SourceTree in fullscreen and almost always I have two projects open: 1 framework project and 1 implementation project. When in fullscreen it is difficult to quickly discern which project is which. Most have same type of branches and tags because both are in sync. If I am unsure I now need to switch to Mission Control and hover over the spaces to see their window titles.

Solution:
Somehow show the project name in the fullscreen window.

Maybe alternative solutions are building a tabbed mode or show up an open project switcher in the navigation switcher so only one fullscreen copy of sourcetree is needed. Solves some window management.
fields.summary: Fullscreen mode does not show project name

fields.description:
I always run SourceTree in fullscreen in its own spaces.

Problem:
When I close the app and reopen it (or reboot mac) it opens my last open projects but not in fullscreen. They are all on my main desktop.

Solution: 
Remember fullscreen mode for Lion resume functionality.
fields.summary: Does not remember fullscreen mode

fields.description:
I regularly work on a larger screen and last time I enlarged the height of the commit dialog for a better overview.

Problem:
Now when I reopen SourceTree to work on my laptop without external screen the bottom parts of the commit dialog is outside the screen. It is impossible to use them to commit my work. I see no way to scale the commit dialog back to a smaller format.

Solution:
Always check the height of the screen and make it impossible to open a dialog that is larger than the screen.
fields.summary: Commit dialog too big when switching to smaller screen.

fields.description:
We have a master branch in which all branches flow back.

When we view our Git history in sourceTree the master is not always the most left branch. This makes it difficult to discern the flow of all the branches.

On the github network graph this is always correct.

Solution:
Make the oldest or master branch always the most left branch in the graph.
fields.summary: Show oldest still open branch at outer left in graph

fields.description:
I often switch branches. When switching branches the dialog "Confirm Branch Switch - Are you sure you want to switch your working copy to the branch 'NAME'" appears. Below it is a "Discard local changes" option. This option appears regardless if there are local changes.

This often confuses me. Most of the time there are no changes but I still want to check. This makes me dismiss the dialog, go to the changes screen, see that there are no changes and then I reopen the dialog to switch for real.

Solution:
Remove or disable the "Discard local changes" option in the dialog when there are no changes. Or show a message that there are no changes.
fields.summary: When switching branches only show the discard local changes option when there are local changes.
